_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The cause and reason why sometimes even: The heart is overcome and mired in sensual desire
The heart is overcome and mired in ill will
The heart is overcome and mired in dullness and drowsiness
The heart is overcome and mired in restlessness and remorse
The heart is overcome and mired in doubt
The examples of bowls of water used to i: A bowl of water mixed with dye
A bowl of water heated by fire, boiling and bubbling
A bowl of water overgrown with moss and aquatic plants
A bowl of water stirred by the wind, churning, swirling, and rippling
A bowl of water that is cloudy, murky, and muddy, hidden in the darkness
A bowl of water that is transparent, clear, and unclouded, brought into the light
The examples of when the heart is not ov: The heart is not overcome and mired in sensual desire
The heart is not overcome and mired in ill will
The heart is not overcome and mired in dullness and drowsiness
The heart is not overcome and mired in restlessness and remorse
The heart is not overcome and mired in doubt
